sn56.43:4.1: “Mendicants, there is a hell called ‘the intense fever’.
sn56.43:4.2: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable;
sn56.43:4.7: Whatever phenomenon you cognize with your mind is unlikable, not likable;
sn56.43:5.1: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha:
sn56.43:5.2: “Sir, that fever really is intense, so very intense.
sn56.43:5.3: Is there any other fever more intense and scarier than this one?”
sn56.43:6.2: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.43:6.3: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.43:6.4: They continue to make such choices …
sn56.43:6.6: Having made such choices, they burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:6.7: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:6.8: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.43:7.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.43:7.3: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …
sn56.43:7.6: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:7.7: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn56.43:7.8: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
sn56.43:8.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
